			<H1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">UCC-1 financing statement</H1>
									<DIV id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
									<DIV id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</DIV>
								<DIV id="contentSub"></DIV>
												<DIV id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<A href="#mw-head">navigation</A>, 					<A href="#p-search">search</A>
				</DIV>
				<DIV id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><DIV class="mw-parser-output"><TABLE class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
<TBODY><TR>
<TD class="mbox-image">
<DIV style="width:52px"><A href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><IMG alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></A></DIV>
</TD>
<TD class="mbox-text">
<DIV class="mbox-text-span">This article <B>needs additional citations for <A href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</A></B>. <SPAN class="hide-when-compact">Please help <A class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=UCC-1_financing_statement&action=edit">improve this article</A> by <A href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">adding citations to reliable sources</A>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</SPAN> <SMALL><I>(October 2014)</I></SMALL> <SMALL class="hide-when-compact"><I>(<A href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</A>)</I></SMALL></DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
</TBODY></TABLE>
<P>A <B>UCC-1 financing statement</B> (an abbreviation for <A href="/wiki/Uniform_Commercial_Code" title="Uniform Commercial Code">Uniform Commercial Code</A>-1) is a legal form that a <A href="/wiki/Creditor" title="Creditor">creditor</A> files to give notice that it has or may have an interest in the personal property of a <A href="/wiki/Debtor" title="Debtor">debtor</A> (a person who owes a debt to the creditor as typically specified in the agreement creating the debt). This form is filed in order to "perfect" a creditor's <A href="/wiki/Security_interest" title="Security interest">security interest</A> by giving public notice that there is a right to take possession of and sell certain assets for repayment of a specific debt with a certain priority. Such notices of sale are often found in the local newspapers. Once the form has been filed, the creditor establishes a relative priority with other creditors of the debtor.<SUP id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-1">[1]</A></SUP> This process is also called "perfecting the security interest" in the property, and this type of loan is a <A href="/wiki/Secured_loan" title="Secured loan">secured loan</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-2">[2]</A></SUP> A financing statement may also be filed in the real estate records by a lessor of fixtures to establish the priority of the lessor's rights against a holder of a mortgage or other lien on the real property. The creditor's rights against the debtor and the lessor's rights against the lessee are based on the credit documents and the lease, respectively, and not the financing statement.</P>
<P>Pursuant to the standards set forth in the UCC, at 9-503 and 9-504, the financing statement need only contain three pieces of information:</P>
<OL>
<LI>the debtor's name and address</LI>
<LI>the creditor's name and address</LI>
<LI>an indication of the collateral, "whether or not it is specific, if it reasonably identifies what is described." (UCC 9-108)</LI>
</OL>
<P>The financing statement is generally filed with the office of the <A href="/wiki/State_secretary_of_state" class="mw-redirect" title="State secretary of state">state secretary of state</A>, in the state where the debtor is located - for an individual, the state where the debtor resides, for most kinds of business organizations the state of incorporation or organization. Many states have a state agency that operates under the secretary of state, which is tasked with overseeing business organizations and activities, including receipt of financing statements. However, an exception exists if the collateral is something that is tied to a particular piece of <A href="/wiki/Real_property" title="Real property">real property</A>, such as <A href="/wiki/Timber" class="mw-redirect" title="Timber">timber</A>, <A href="/wiki/Mineral_rights" title="Mineral rights">mineral rights</A>, or <A href="/wiki/Fixture_(property_law)" title="Fixture (property law)">fixtures</A>. In that case, the filing must be made in the county where the property is located, usually in the recording office or county court, because that is where third parties are most likely to search for such record.</P>
<P>In the case of a loan secured by personal property collateral, the filing of a financing statement gives notice of a <A href="/wiki/Lien" title="Lien">lien</A> against the property so that other lenders or buyers of the personal property will know of the security interest. In the case of a filing of a financing statement by a lessor of fixtures, the filing of the financing statement gives notice of the lessor's interests to others who acquire an interest in the real property and related fixtures. The financing statement does not create a lien nor does it create any additional rights against a lessee in favor of a lessor, the filing of a financing statement just gives notice of whatever rights the creditor or lessor have under their loan documents or lease, respectively.</P>

<H1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Philippe Petit</H1>			<DIV id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
				<DIV id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</DIV>				<DIV id="contentSub"></DIV>
								<DIV id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<A href="#mw-head">navigation</A>, 					<A href="#p-search">search</A>
				</DIV>
				<DIV id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><DIV class="mw-parser-output"><TABLE class="infobox biography vcard" style="width:22em">
<TBODY><TR>
<TH colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><SPAN class="fn">Philippe Petit</SPAN></TH>
</TR>
<TR>
<TD colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><A href="/wiki/File:PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg" class="image"><IMG alt="PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg/220px-PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg" width="220" height="277" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg/330px-PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg/440px-PhilippePetitAAFeb09.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1100" data-file-height="1386" /></A>
<DIV>Petit at the <A href="/wiki/81st_Academy_Awards" title="81st Academy Awards">81st Academy Awards</A> in February 2009</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TH scope="row">Born</TH>
<TD><SPAN style="display:none">(<SPAN class="bday">1949-08-13</SPAN>)</SPAN> 13 August 1949 <SPAN class="noprint ForceAgeToShow">(age 68)</SPAN><BR />
<SPAN class="birthplace"><A href="/wiki/Nemours" title="Nemours">Nemours</A>, <A href="/wiki/Seine-et-Marne" title="Seine-et-Marne">Seine-et-Marne</A>, France</SPAN></TD>
</TR>
<TR>
<TH scope="row">Occupation</TH>
<TD class="role"><A href="/wiki/Tightrope_walking" title="Tightrope walking">High-wire artist</A></TD>
</TR>
</TBODY></TABLE>
<P><B>Philippe Petit</B> (<SMALL>French pronunciation: ​</SMALL><SPAN title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><A href="/wiki/Help:IPA/French" title="Help:IPA/French">[filip pəti]</A></SPAN>; born 13 August 1949) is a <A href="/wiki/French_people" title="French people">French</A> <A href="/wiki/Tightrope_walking" title="Tightrope walking">high-wire artist</A> who gained fame for his high-wire walk between the Twin Towers of the <A href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</A> in New York City, on the morning of August 7, 1974 as well as his high wire walk between the Notre Dame cathedral in Paris, 1971.<SUP id="cite_ref-grace_1-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-grace-1">[1]</A></SUP> For his unauthorized feat 400 metres (1,000 feet) above the ground – which he referred to as "le coup"<SUP id="cite_ref-manonwire_2-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-manonwire-2">[2]</A></SUP> – he rigged a 200-kilogram (440-pound) cable and used a custom-made 8-metre (30-foot) long, 25-kilogram (55-pound) balancing pole. He performed for 45 minutes, making eight passes along the wire. The following week, he celebrated his 25th birthday. All charges were dismissed in exchange for him doing a performance in Central Park for children.</P>
<P>Since then, Petit has lived in New York, where he has been artist-in-residence at the <A href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_St._John_the_Divine" class="mw-redirect" title="Cathedral of St. John the Divine">Cathedral of St. John the Divine</A>, also a location of other aerial performances. He has done wire walking as part of official celebrations in New York, across the United States, and in France and other countries, as well as teaching workshops on the art. In 2008, <I><A href="/wiki/Man_on_Wire" title="Man on Wire">Man on Wire</A></I>, a documentary directed by <A href="/wiki/James_Marsh_(director)" title="James Marsh (director)">James Marsh</A> about Petit's walk between the towers, won numerous awards. He was also the subject of a children's book and an animated adaptation of it, released in 2005. <I><A href="/wiki/The_Walk_(2015_film)" title="The Walk (2015 film)">The Walk</A></I>, a movie based on Petit's walk, was released in September 2015, starring <A href="/wiki/Joseph_Gordon-Levitt" title="Joseph Gordon-Levitt">Joseph Gordon-Levitt</A> as Petit and directed by <A href="/wiki/Robert_Zemeckis" title="Robert Zemeckis">Robert Zemeckis</A>.</P>
<P>He also became adept at <A href="/wiki/Equestrianism" title="Equestrianism">equestrianism</A>, <A href="/wiki/Juggling" title="Juggling">juggling</A>, <A href="/wiki/Fencing" title="Fencing">fencing</A>, <A href="/wiki/Carpentry" title="Carpentry">carpentry</A>, <A href="/wiki/Rock-climbing" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock-climbing">rock-climbing</A>, and <A href="/wiki/Bullfighting" title="Bullfighting">bullfighting</A>. Spurning circuses and their formulaic performances, he created his street persona on the sidewalks of Paris. In the early 1970s, he visited New York City, where he frequently juggled and worked on a <A href="/wiki/Slacklining" title="Slacklining">slackline</A> in <A href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</A>.</P>
<P></P>

<P></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>Petit was born in <A href="/wiki/Nemours" title="Nemours">Nemours</A>, <A href="/wiki/Seine-et-Marne" title="Seine-et-Marne">Seine-et-Marne</A>, France; his father Edmond Petit was an author and an Army pilot. At an early age, Petit discovered magic and juggling. He loved to climb, and at 16, he took his first steps on a tightrope wire. He told a reporter,</P>
<BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>Within one year, I taught myself to do all the things you could do on a wire. I learned the backward somersault, the front somersault, the unicycle, the bicycle, the chair on the wire, jumping through hoops. But I thought, "What is the big deal here? It looks almost ugly." So I started to discard those tricks and to reinvent my art.<SUP id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-3">[3]</A></SUP></P>
</BLOCKQUOTE>
<P>In June 1971, Petit secretly installed a cable between the two towers of <A href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_de_Paris" class="mw-redirect" title="Notre Dame de Paris">Notre Dame de Paris</A>. On the morning of June 26, 1971, he "juggled balls" and "pranced back and forth" as the crowd below applauded.<SUP id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-4">[4]</A></SUP></P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="World_Trade_Center_walk">World Trade Center walk</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: World Trade Center walk">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>Before his Twin Towers walk, Petit was known to New Yorkers for his frequent tightrope-walking performances and magic shows in the parks of New York, especially <A href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</A>. Petit's most famous performance was in August 1974, conducted on a wire between the roofs of the Twin Towers of the <A href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</A> in Manhattan, a quarter mile above the ground. He performed for 45 minutes, making eight passes along the wire, during which he walked, danced, lay down on the wire, and saluted watchers from a kneeling position. Office workers, construction crews and policemen cheered him on.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Planning">Planning</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: Planning">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Petit conceived his "coup" when he was 18, when he first read about the proposed construction of the Twin Towers and saw drawings of the project in a magazine, which he read while sitting at a dentist's office in 1968.<SUP id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-5">[5]</A></SUP> Petit was seized by the idea of performing there, and began collecting articles on the Towers whenever he could.</P>
<P>What was called the "artistic crime of the century" took Petit six years of planning, during which he learned everything he could about the buildings and their construction. In the same period, he began to perform high wire walking at other famous places. Rigging his wire secretly, he performed as a combination of circus act and public display. In 1971, he performed his first such walk between the towers of the cathedral of <A href="/wiki/Notre_Dame_de_Paris" class="mw-redirect" title="Notre Dame de Paris">Notre Dame de Paris</A>,<SUP id="cite_ref-grace_1-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-grace-1">[1]</A></SUP> while priests were simultaneously being ordained inside the building. In 1973, he walked a wire rigged between the two north pylons of the <A href="/wiki/Sydney_Harbour_Bridge" title="Sydney Harbour Bridge">Sydney Harbour Bridge</A>, in <A href="/wiki/Sydney,_Australia" class="mw-redirect" title="Sydney, Australia">Sydney, Australia</A>.<SUP id="cite_ref-wire_6-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-wire-6">[6]</A></SUP></P>
<P>In planning for the Twin Towers walk, Petit had to learn how to accommodate such issues as the swaying of the high towers due to wind, which was part of their design; effects of wind and weather on the wire at that height, how to rig a 200 ft (61 m) steel cable across the 138 ft (42 m) gap between the towers (at a height of 1,368 ft (417 m)), and how to gain entry with his collaborators, first to scope out the conditions and lastly, to stage the project.<SUP id="cite_ref-manonwire_2-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-manonwire-2">[2]</A></SUP> They had to get heavy equipment to the rooftops. He traveled to New York on numerous occasions to make first-hand observations.<SUP id="cite_ref-grace_1-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-grace-1">[1]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Since the towers were still under construction, Petit and one of his collaborators, New York-based photographer <A href="/wiki/Jim_Moore_(photographer)" title="Jim Moore (photographer)">Jim Moore</A>, rented a helicopter to take aerial photographs of the buildings.<SUP id="cite_ref-manonwire_2-2" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-manonwire-2">[2]</A></SUP> Jean-François and Jean-Louis helped him practice in a field in France, and accompanied him to take part in the final rigging of the project, as well as to photograph it. <A href="/wiki/Francis_Brunn" title="Francis Brunn">Francis Brunn</A>, a German juggler, provided financial support for the proposed project and its planning.<SUP id="cite_ref-second_7-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-second-7">[7]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Petit and his crew gained entry into the towers several times and hid in upper floors and on the roofs of the unfinished buildings in order to study security measures, in addition to analyzing the construction and identifying places to anchor the wire and <A href="/wiki/Cavalletti" class="mw-redirect" title="Cavalletti">cavalletti</A><SUP class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<I><A href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><SPAN title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (June 2017)">dubious</SPAN></A> <SPAN class="metadata">– <A href="/wiki/Talk:Philippe_Petit#Dubious" title="Talk:Philippe Petit">discuss</A></SPAN></I>]</SUP>. Using his own observations, drawings, and Moore's photographs, Petit constructed a scale model of the towers in order to design the needed rigging to prepare for the wire walk.</P>
<P>Working from an ID of an American who worked in the building, Petit made fake identification cards for himself and his collaborators (claiming that they were contractors who were installing an electrified fence on the roof) to gain access to the buildings. Prior to this, Petit had carefully observed the clothes worn by construction workers and the kinds of tools they carried. He also took note of the clothing of office workers so that some of his collaborators could pose as white collar workers. He observed what time the workers arrived and left, so he could determine when he would have roof access.</P>
<P>As the target date of his "coup" approached, he claimed to be a journalist with <I>Metropolis</I>, a French architecture magazine, so that he could gain permission to interview the workers on the roof. The Port Authority allowed Petit to conduct the interviews, which he used as a pretext to make more observations. He was once caught by a police officer on the roof, and his hopes to do the high-wire walk were dampened. He eventually regained the confidence to proceed.</P>
<P>On the night of Tuesday, 6 August 1974, Petit and his crew had a lucky break and got a ride in a freight elevator to the 110th floor with their equipment. They stored it just 19 steps below the roof. In order to pass the cable across the void, Petit and his crew had settled on using a bow and arrow attached to a rope. They had to practice this many times to perfect their technique. They first shot across a fishing line, which was attached to larger ropes, and finally to the 450-pound steel cable. The team was delayed when the heavy cable sank too fast, and had to be pulled up manually for hours. Petit had already identified points at which to anchor two tiranti (<A href="/wiki/Guy-wire" title="Guy-wire">guy lines</A>) to other points to stabilize the cable and keep the swaying of the wire to a minimum.<SUP id="cite_ref-manonwire_2-3" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-manonwire-2">[2]</A></SUP></P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Event">Event</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: Event">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>Shortly after 7 am local time, Petit stepped out on the wire and started to perform. He was 1350 feet (411 m), a quarter mile, above the ground. He performed for 45 minutes, making eight passes along the wire, during which he walked, danced, lay down on the wire, and knelt to salute watchers. Crowds gathered on the streets below, and he said later he could hear their murmuring and cheers.</P>
<P>When <A href="/wiki/NYPD" class="mw-redirect" title="NYPD">NYPD</A> and <A href="/wiki/PAPD" class="mw-redirect" title="PAPD">PAPD</A> officers learned of his stunt, they came up to the roofs of both buildings to try to persuade him to get off the wire. They threatened to pluck him off by helicopter.<SUP class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<I><A href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><SPAN title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2018)">citation needed</SPAN></A></I>]</SUP> Petit got off when it started to rain.</P>
<H3><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Aftermath">Aftermath</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: Aftermath">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H3>
<P>There was extensive news coverage and public appreciation of Petit's high-wire walk; the district attorney dropped all formal charges of trespassing and other items relating to his walk.<SUP id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-8">[8]</A></SUP> In exchange, he was required to give a free aerial show for children in Central Park. He performed on a high-wire walk in the Park above Belvedere Lake (known now as <A href="/wiki/Great_Lawn_and_Turtle_Pond,_Central_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Lawn and Turtle Pond, Central Park">Turtle Pond</A>).</P>
<P>The <A href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">Port Authority of New York and New Jersey</A> gave Petit a lifetime pass to the Twin Towers' Observation Deck. He autographed a steel beam close to the point where he began his walk.</P>
<P>Petit's high-wire walk is credited with bringing the Twin Towers much needed attention and even affection, as they initially had been unpopular.<SUP id="cite_ref-query.nytimes.com_9-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-query.nytimes.com-9">[9]</A></SUP><SUP id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-10">[10]</A></SUP> Critics such as historian <A href="/wiki/Lewis_Mumford" title="Lewis Mumford">Lewis Mumford</A> had regarded them as ugly and utilitarian in design, and too large a development for the area. The Port Authority was having trouble renting out all of the office space.<SUP id="cite_ref-query.nytimes.com_9-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-query.nytimes.com-9">[9]</A></SUP></P>
<P><A href="/wiki/Mordicai_Gerstein" title="Mordicai Gerstein">Mordicai Gerstein</A> wrote and illustrated a children's book, <A href="/wiki/The_Man_Who_Walked_Between_the_Towers" title="The Man Who Walked Between the Towers"><I>The Man Who Walked Between The Towers</I></A> (2003), which won a <A href="/wiki/Caldecott_Medal" title="Caldecott Medal">Caldecott Medal</A> for his art. It was adapted and produced as an animated short film by the same title, directed by <A href="/wiki/Michael_Sporn" title="Michael Sporn">Michael Sporn</A> and released in 2005, which won several awards.</P>
<P>The documentary film <I><A href="/wiki/Man_on_Wire" title="Man on Wire">Man on Wire</A></I> (2008) by UK director <A href="/wiki/James_Marsh_(director)" title="James Marsh (director)">James Marsh</A> is about Petit and his 1974 WTC performance; it won both the World Cinema Jury and Audience awards at the <A href="/wiki/2008_Sundance_Film_Festival" title="2008 Sundance Film Festival">Sundance Film Festival 2008</A>. It combines historical footage with re-enactment and has the spirit of a heist film. It also won awards at the 2008 <A href="/wiki/Full_Frame_Documentary_Film_Festival" title="Full Frame Documentary Film Festival">Full Frame Documentary Film Festival</A> in <A href="/wiki/Durham,_North_Carolina" title="Durham, North Carolina">Durham, North Carolina</A>, and the <A href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Documentary" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award for Best Documentary">Academy Award for Best Documentary</A> in 2009. On stage with Marsh to accept the Oscar award, Petit made a coin vanish in his hands while thanking the Academy "for believing in magic". He balanced the Oscar by its head on his chin to cheers from the audience.<SUP id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-11">[11]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Petit's memoir was adapted into a biographical drama entitled <I><A href="/wiki/The_Walk_(2015_film)" title="The Walk (2015 film)">The Walk</A></I> (2015), directed by <A href="/wiki/Robert_Zemeckis" title="Robert Zemeckis">Robert Zemeckis</A> and starring <A href="/wiki/Joseph_Gordon-Levitt" title="Joseph Gordon-Levitt">Joseph Gordon-Levitt</A> as Petit.</P>
<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="Later_life">Later life</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: Later life">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<P>Petit has made dozens of public high-wire performances in his career; in 1986 he re-enacted the crossing of the <A href="/wiki/Niagara_River" title="Niagara River">Niagara River</A> by <A href="/wiki/Blondin" class="mw-redirect" title="Blondin">Blondin</A> for an <A href="/wiki/IMAX" title="IMAX">IMAX</A> film. In 1989, to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution, mayor <A href="/wiki/Jacques_Chirac" title="Jacques Chirac">Jacques Chirac</A> invited him to walk an inclined wire strung from the ground at the <A href="/wiki/Place_du_Trocad%C3%A9ro" class="mw-redirect" title="Place du Trocadéro">Place du Trocadéro</A> to the second level of the <A href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</A>, crossing the <A href="/wiki/Seine" title="Seine">Seine</A>.</P>
<P>Petit briefly headlined with the <A href="/wiki/Ringling_Brothers_Circus" title="Ringling Brothers Circus">Ringling Brothers Circus</A>, but preferred staging his own performances. During his stint with the circus and a practice walk, he suffered his only fall, from 45 feet (14 m), breaking several ribs. He says he has never fallen during a performance. "If I had, I wouldn't be here talking about it."<SUP id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-12">[12]</A></SUP></P>
<P>Petit regularly gives lectures and workshops internationally on a variety of topics and subjects. He single-handedly built a barn in the <A href="/wiki/Catskill_Mountains" title="Catskill Mountains">Catskill Mountains</A> using the methods and tools of 18th-century timber framers.<SUP id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-13">[13]</A></SUP> He wrote his eighth book, <I>A Square Peg</I>. He has also created an ebook for <A href="/wiki/TED_Books" class="mw-redirect" title="TED Books">TED Books</A>, entitled <I>Cheating the Impossible: Ideas and Recipes from a Rebellious High-Wire Artist</I>. Petit divides his time between New York City, where he is an <A href="/wiki/Artist_in_residence" class="mw-redirect" title="Artist in residence">artist in residence</A> at the <A href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Saint_John_the_Divine,_New_York" class="mw-redirect" title="Cathedral of Saint John the Divine, New York">Cathedral of Saint John the Divine</A>, and a hideaway in the Catskill Mountains.</P>
<P>Among those who have associated with some of his projects are such artists as: <A href="/wiki/Mikhail_Baryshnikov" title="Mikhail Baryshnikov">Mikhail Baryshnikov</A>, <A href="/wiki/Werner_Herzog" title="Werner Herzog">Werner Herzog</A>, <A href="/wiki/Annie_Leibovitz" title="Annie Leibovitz">Annie Leibovitz</A>, <A href="/wiki/Milo%C5%A1_Forman" title="Miloš Forman">Miloš Forman</A>, <A href="/wiki/Volker_Schl%C3%B6ndorff" title="Volker Schlöndorff">Volker Schlöndorff</A>, <A href="/wiki/Twyla_Tharp" title="Twyla Tharp">Twyla Tharp</A>, <A href="/wiki/Peter_Beard" title="Peter Beard">Peter Beard</A>, <A href="/wiki/Marcel_Marceau" title="Marcel Marceau">Marcel Marceau</A>, <A href="/wiki/Paul_Auster" title="Paul Auster">Paul Auster</A>, <A href="/wiki/Paul_Winter" title="Paul Winter">Paul Winter</A>, <A href="/wiki/Debra_Winger" title="Debra Winger">Debra Winger</A>, <A href="/wiki/Robin_Williams" title="Robin Williams">Robin Williams</A> and <A href="/wiki/Sting_(musician)" title="Sting (musician)">Sting</A>.<SUP class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<I><A href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><SPAN title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</SPAN></A></I>]</SUP> Director <A href="/wiki/James_Signorelli" title="James Signorelli">James Signorelli</A> assisted with the creation of the book <I>To Reach the Clouds</I> (2002), about the Twin Towers walk.<SUP id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-14">[14]</A></SUP> In the book, Petit not only wrote about his spectacular feat, and the events of his life which led up to it, but also expressed his feelings following the <A href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11 attacks</A> during which the Twin Towers were destroyed. He wrote that on that morning, "My towers became our towers. I saw them collapse – hurling, crushing thousands of lives. Disbelief preceded sorrow for the obliteration of the buildings, perplexity descended before rage at the unbearable loss of life."<SUP id="cite_ref-auto_15-0" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-auto-15">[15]</A></SUP> Besides paying tribute to those who were killed, Petit also called for a rebuilding of the towers, promising that "When the towers again twin-tickle the clouds, I offer to walk again, to be the expression of the builders' collective voice. Together, we will rejoice in an aerial song of victory." <SUP id="cite_ref-auto_15-1" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-auto-15">[15]</A></SUP> Notwithstanding Petit's wishes, the Twin Towers were eventually replaced by <A href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="World Trade Center (2001–present)">a different complex of buildings</A>, thus precluding the possibility of Petit (or anyone else) repeating a similar feat at the World Trade Center site.</P>

<H2><SPAN class="mw-headline" id="In_culture">In culture</SPAN><SPAN class="mw-editsection"><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</SPAN><A href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Petit&action=edit&section=12&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro" title="Edit section: In culture">edit</A><SPAN class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</SPAN></SPAN></H2>
<UL>
<LI>The song, "Man on Wire" by the band <A href="/wiki/27_(band)" title="27 (band)">27</A> is a tribute to Philippe Petit.<SUP id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-19">[19]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI>The song, "Sleepwalking," by Danish composer <A href="/wiki/Ste_van_Holm" title="Ste van Holm">Ste van Holm</A> is a tribute to Petit's World Trade Center walk.<SUP id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-20">[20]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/The_Low_Anthem" title="The Low Anthem">The Low Anthem</A>'s song, "Boeing 737", from their 2011 album <I><A href="/wiki/Smart_Flesh" title="Smart Flesh">Smart Flesh</A>,</I> refers to Petit's Twin Towers walk.<SUP id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-21">[21]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI>American rock band <A href="/wiki/Incubus_(band)" title="Incubus (band)">Incubus</A> used a photo of Petit as the cover art for their album, <I><A href="/wiki/If_Not_Now,_When%3F_(album)" title="If Not Now, When? (album)">If Not Now, When?</A></I> (2011).</LI>
<LI><A href="/wiki/Colum_McCann" title="Colum McCann">Colum McCann</A>'s <A href="/wiki/National_Book_Award" title="National Book Award">National Book Award</A>-winning novel, <I><A href="/wiki/Let_the_Great_World_Spin" title="Let the Great World Spin">Let the Great World Spin</A></I> (2009), features Petit's Twin Towers walk as its opening passage and a centrepiece to which numerous characters are connected.</LI>
<LI>"Funambulist", a song by American metal band <A href="/wiki/Cormorant_(band)" title="Cormorant (band)">Cormorant</A>, is about his walk between the Twin Towers.<SUP id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-22">[22]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI>The song "Step Out Of The Void" by musician <A href="/wiki/Howard_Moss" title="Howard Moss">Howard Moss</A> is a tribute to Philippe Petit, in the album <I>Outside the Pale</I> (2013).<SUP id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-23">[23]</A></SUP></LI>
<LI>The song "Man On A Wire" by <A href="/wiki/The_Script" title="The Script">The Script</A> on their fourth album, <I><A href="/wiki/No_Sound_Without_Silence" title="No Sound Without Silence">No Sound Without Silence</A></I>, is influenced by Petit's high-wire legacy.</LI>
<LI>The song "Stand Up Comedy" by <A href="/wiki/U2" title="U2">U2</A> on their twelfth album, <I><A href="/wiki/No_Line_On_The_Horizon" class="mw-redirect" title="No Line On The Horizon">No Line On The Horizon</A></I>, references "The wire is stretched in between our two towers".</LI>
<LI>Petit was the inspiration for the 5th Anniversary 9/11 cover of <I><A href="/wiki/The_New_Yorker" title="The New Yorker">The New Yorker</A></I> magazine (Sep. 11, 2006), "Soaring Spirit", by John Mavroudis (concept) and Owen Smith (art). That cover was named Cover of the Year by the American Society of Magazine Editors (ASME).<SUP id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><A href="#cite_note-24">[24]</A></SUP> The two-part cover was a first for <I>The New Yorker</I>.</LI>
</UL>
